items.title: TTPs fail to serialize Kill_Chains when no TTP is set on object
items.body: Issue present in both `master` and `stix1.1.1`. Since there is no nice way to overcome this issue, the proposed solution is to remove EntityList functionality on the class and refer to variables separately.

items.title: Fail to create an AIS marking object whose tlp color is red.
items.body:
Hi,

I tried to create an AIS marking object whose tlp color is RED.
But an exception was occured.

I checked the source.

python-stix/stix/extensions/marking/ais.py

`
_ALLOWED_VALUES = ('WHITE', 'GREEN', 'AMBER')
`

It seems to suppress other than WHITE, GREEN, AMBER.
Is this a specification behavior?

If it is a right behavior, I would like to know why the value of TLP is suppresseed.

Thanks!

items.title: _element_type not filled in for PersonNameElement
items.body:
It seems like you can specify the alias for an identity using the CIQ stuff.

``` xml
<xnl:PersonName xnl:Type="Alias">
     <xnl:NameElement>Rodney</xnl:NameElement>
</xnl:PersonName>
```

This information doesn't seem to be captured.  It would be helpful for the elevator in order to fill in the alias property of certain STIX 2.1 objects.

items.title: Namespace not found: http://xml/metadataSharing.xsd
items.body:
We have an internal project using both Java and Python with their corresponding latest STIX libraries for STIX 1.1.1. When an XML document is generated using the following Java code:

```java
import org.mitre.stix.stix_1.STIXPackage;

public class Hello {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println(new STIXPackage().withVersion("1.1.1").toXMLString(true));
    }
}
```

there is always a line `http://xml/metadataSharing.xsd` in it:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<stix:STIX_Package version="1.1.1"
    xmlns="http://xml/metadataSharing.xsd" xmlns:stix="http://stix.mitre.org/stix-1"/>
```

The schema exists in the official [document](http://stix.mitre.org/language/version1.1.1/xsddocs/XMLSchema/extensions/malware/maec_4.1/1.0.1/metadataSharing_xsd.html). The XML document can also pass the validation (STIX Document Validator v2.5.0):

```sh
$ cat ./test1.xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<stix:STIX_Package version="1.1.1"
    xmlns="http://xml/metadataSharing.xsd" xmlns:stix="http://stix.mitre.org/stix-1"/>
$ stix-validator.py --stix-version 1.1.1 ./test1.xml
[-] Performing xml schema validation on ./test1.xml
================================================================================
[-] Results: ./test1.xml
[+] XML Schema: True
```

However, for the following Python program:

```python
import sys

from stix.core import STIXPackage


def main():
    pkg = STIXPackage.from_xml(sys.argv[1])
    print(pkg.to_xml().decode())


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

it failed:

```sh
$ ./venv/bin/python ./test.py ./test1.xml
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/chehsunliu/testzone/python/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/mixbox/namespaces.py", line 205, in __lookup_uri
    return self.__ns_uri_map[uri]
KeyError: 'http://xml/metadataSharing.xsd'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./test.py", line 14, in <module>
    main()
  File "./test.py", line 10, in main
    print(pkg.to_xml().decode())
  File "/Users/chehsunliu/testzone/python/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/stix/base.py", line 142, in to_xml
    ns_info.finalize(ns_dict=ns_dict, schemaloc_dict=schemaloc_dict)
  File "/Users/chehsunliu/testzone/python/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/mixbox/entities.py", line 903, in finalize
    self._finalize_namespaces(ns_dict)
  File "/Users/chehsunliu/testzone/python/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/mixbox/entities.py", line 847, in _finalize_namespaces
    prefix = namespaces.lookup_name(ns_uri)
  File "/Users/chehsunliu/testzone/python/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/mixbox/namespaces.py", line 859, in lookup_name
    return __ALL_NAMESPACES.preferred_prefix_for_namespace(ns_uri)
  File "/Users/chehsunliu/testzone/python/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/mixbox/namespaces.py", line 291, in preferred_prefix_for_namespace
    ni = self.__lookup_uri(ns_uri)
  File "/Users/chehsunliu/testzone/python/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/mixbox/namespaces.py", line 207, in __lookup_uri
    raise NamespaceNotFoundError(uri)
mixbox.namespaces.NamespaceNotFoundError: Namespace not found: http://xml/metadataSharing.xsd
```

items.title: Add note to documentation about memory consumption in python-cybox

milestone.description: This Milestone is for capturing issues that need to be addressed simultaneously in 1.2.0.x and 1.1.1.x for the next releases in both branches.

items.body: See https://github.com/STIXProject/python-stix/issues/351#issuecomment-396643607 and CybOXProject/python-cybox#317.

items.title: RAM consumption
items.body:
I'm having an issue with RAM consumption. It seems that when i process a lot of files (several thousand but one after another) im running out of RAM and i think it shouldn't happen in this situation.
When using the following code eventually my program gets killed because the OS is running out of RAM.
I have also tried to implement an easy way to monitor the storage usage. You can see that more and more dict objects are created (and not deleted i guess) which take more and more RAM.
If i run the xmltodict parser instead everything works just fine (but it is harder to access the data).

```python
from stix.core import STIXPackage
from pympler import summary
from pympler import muppy
#import xmltodict

# define a list of paths
paths = ...

n = 0
for path in paths:
    if n%10 == 0:
        sum = summary.summarize(muppy.get_objects())
        summary.print_(sum)
        n = 0
    # I've got no issues when parsing with xmltodict
    #with open(path, "rb") as file:
        #data_dicts = xmltodict.parse(file)
    stix_package = STIXPackage.from_xml(path)
    data_dicts = stix_package.to_dict()
    n += 1
```

The short version of my output is something like this:

| types | objects | total size |
| ------------- | ------------- |  ------------- |
| <class 'dict  | 6680 | 3.45 MB |
| ...  | ... | ... |
| <class 'dict  | 40947 | 11.29 MB |
| ...  | ... | ... |
| <class 'dict  | 100243 | 28.67 MB |
| and | so | on |
| <class 'dict  | 176329| 50.51 MB |

The number of objects and the storage consumption keeps rising. 

Thanks for your help!

items.title: to_json fails on parsing datetime
items.body:
I tried to parse the following stix document using to_json:
https://www.eclecticiq.com/downloads/EclecticIQ-Fusion-Center-Report-Thanatos-Ransomware.zip
But it seems like there is a problem with datetime with both python 2.7 and 3.6

![screenshot from 2018-02-27 15-34-30](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16307976/36740036-a05f8eda-1be1-11e8-94ea-4e0b742404c4.png)

![screenshot from 2018-02-27 15-38-08](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16307976/36740083-b9e4e472-1be1-11e8-942c-6d4698c2bc27.png)

items.title: [Python3 not supported - v1.1/1.2] to_json vaguely broken on some files
items.body:
tl;rd: python3 support is broken in the version 1.1 and 1.2 of the library.

If the XML file contains a TTP in MAEC format, it  is not properly converted back to string, making to_json fail.

Example: 
```'ttps': {'ttps': [{'behavior': {'malware_instances': [{'maec': b'<stix-maec:MAEC xmlns:stix-maec="http://stix.mitre.org/extensions/Malware#MAEC4.1-1"...```

I'm pretty sure this problem will happen in many other cases.

items.title: VocabTypes are unhashable in 1.1.1.x on Python 3
items.body: This is the root cause behind oasis-open/cti-stix-elevator#93. This is fixed in the master branch, but we need a release of python-stix 1.1.1.x that addresses this.

items.title: Create multiple "contacts" in "Incident"
items.body:
[Incident](https://github.com/STIXProject/python-stix/blob/master/stix/incident/__init__.py)
> contacts = fields.TypedField("Contact", InformationSource, multiple=True, key_name="contacts")
Above field is specified in "Incident" class but there is no function or procedure to add multiple contacts.

Is there any workaround for it?

items.title: Report field ttp has the wrong type information
items.body: There should be a type stix.report.ttps, but it apparently was never created, so in  https://github.com/STIXProject/python-stix/commit/33c0b5c07866b3b40cfb9586a4b74c53062ec7ba it was changed to stix.core.ttps.TTPs - which does not allow entries with idrefs.

items.title: Documentation: Data Markings page seems redundant
items.body:
The examples seem the same - what is the distinction?

To get a list of the granular markings on an object, pass the object and a list of selectors to get_markings:

In [20]:
malware.get_markings('name')
Out[20]:
['marking-definition--613f2e26-407d-48c7-9eca-b8e91df99dc9']
You can also call get_markings() as a method on the STIX object.

In [14]:
malware.get_markings('name')
Out[14]:
['marking-definition--613f2e26-407d-48c7-9eca-b8e91df99dc9']

items.title: Documentation:  CompositeDataSource Examples seems wrong
items.body:
# get an object that is only in the filesystem
ta = cs.get('intrusion-set--f3bdec95-3d62-42d9-a840-29630f6cdc1a')
print(ta)

# get an object that is only in the TAXII collection
ind = cs.get('indicator--37a6a5de-a5b9-425a-903a-4ae9cbf1ff3f')
print(ind)

This is an example of an invalid XML fragment emitted by the AIS marking binding.

```xml
<AIS:AISMarkingStructure
        xmlns:AIS="http://www.us-cert.gov/STIXMarkingStructure#AISConsentMarking-2"
        xmlns:marking="http://data-marking.mitre.org/Marking-1"
        xmlns:example="http://example.com"
        xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"
        xmlns:ds="http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#"
        xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
        xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xsi:type=b'"AIS:AISMarkingStructure"'>
    <AIS:Is_Proprietary CISA_Proprietary="true">
        <AIS:AISConsent consent="EVERYONE"/>
        <AIS:TLPMarking color="AMBER"/>
    </AIS:Is_Proprietary>
</AIS:AISMarkingStructure>
```

Note the `b'"AIS:AISMarkingStructure"'` in the middle. Looks like Unicode strings and byte strings are getting improperly mixed.

items.title: Incongruity between Campaign/CampaignRef Timestamps
items.body:
I noticed recently that there's an incongruity between timestamp values when using the auto-generated value in a Campaign and then using this value in a CampaignRef. Essentially, the auto-generated timestamp value includes an extra "+00:00" timezone value instead of just using the Zulu time specification ("Z"). This causes a mismatch between the two values which can show up in best-practice validation using the `stix-validator`. 

E.g., the Campaign timestamp would be `2015-04-14T14:46:59.026098+00:00`, and the referenced value would be `2015-04-14T14:46:59.026098Z`. 

Here's some code that will reproduce the issue:

``` python
from stix.campaign import Campaign
from stix.core import STIXPackage
from stix.common import CampaignRef
from stix.indicator import Indicator

c = Campaign()
cref = CampaignRef(idref=c.id_,timestamp=c.timestamp)
i = Indicator()
i.add_related_campaign(cref)
stix_package = STIXPackage()
stix_package.add_campaign(c)
stix_package.add_indicator(i)

```

Also, here's the type of output that the `stix-validator` gives with regards to this:

```
[!] Timestamp Use
        [-] line : 25
        [-] message : IDREF and timestamp combination do not resolve to a node in the input document.
        [-] id : None
        [-] idref : example:campaign-a442247b-347b-4062-a79d-cf2fe8169ef0
        [-] tag : {http://stix.mitre.org/common-1}Campaign
        [-] timestamp : 2015-04-14T14:55:39.469562Z
```

items.title: Remove work-in-progress label from API documentation
items.body: I think the documentation is relatively stable and thorough at this point.

items.title: Set include_schemalocs default value to False in to_xml()
items.body:
`xsi:schemaLocation` shouldn't be used for validation, so we should disable this by default. If users want to include the `xsi:schemaLocation` attribute, they can pass in `include_schemalocs=True` to `to_xml()`.

This may impact python-cybox as well.

items.title: Implement multiple descriptions
items.body:
This is in reference to https://github.com/STIXProject/schemas/issues/186
- Add support for `@ordinality` on `stix.common.StructuredText`
- Add `descriptions` property to places where there is a `description` property.
  - `description` becomes a sort of `descriptions[0]`
  - `descriptions` returns an ordered list, sorted by `ordinality`
  - `descriptions` could be a mapping type, keyed off of `ordinality` rather than raw index (this might be kinda weird in use).

items.title: Add COA_Requested to Incident
items.body: It looks like we added `COA_Taken` in #131, but never added `COA_Requested`

items.title: Add support for references field on Vulnerability
items.body: The `stix.exploit_target.vulnerabiliy.Vulnerability` class does not have support for the `references` field.

items.title: Is <campaign:Names> handled correctly?
items.body:
Campaign.names should support a list of names, but if I try:

```
campaign.names = []
campaign.names.append(VocabString(campaign_id_item))
```

I get:

>    stixXML.write(pkg.to_xml())
>  File "C:\Users\rpiazza\python-stix\stix\base.py", line 91, in to_xml
>    obj = self.to_obj(ns_info=ns_info)
>  File "C:\Users\rpiazza\python-stix\stix\core\stix_package.py", line 299, in to_obj
>    coas_obj.Campaign = [x.to_obj(ns_info=ns_info) for x in self.campaigns]
>  File "C:\Users\rpiazza\python-stix\stix\campaign__init__.py", line 281, in to_obj
>    return_obj.Names = self.names.to_obj(ns_info=ns_info)
> AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'to_obj'

items.title: to_xml() should document that it produces a character-encoded string
items.body: I'd prefer that it would produce a Unicode string which the user is free to encode, but I'll take what I can get. The docs say to_xml() produces an "XML String", which is unnecessarily vague. It should specify that the object returned is a str type, encoded according to the encoding in stix.bindings.ExternalEncoding. I realize that there are other tickets related to to_xml() and Unicode floating around, but it didn't seem appropriate to add this comment to any of them.

items.title: Check for optional data members in GenericTestMechanism
items.body:
When creating an instance of GTM within a package, if data members like 'type' or 'description' are omitted then STIXPackage.to_xml() will emit an error attempting to call `to_obj()` on an object of type None.

This is unintended, as those fields are optional. Can be fixed by checking for the existence of those data members prior to operating on them.

Bug [lives here](https://github.com/STIXProject/python-stix/blob/master/stix/extensions/test_mechanism/generic_test_mechanism.py#L78):

Repro:

```
indicator = Indicator(title = "Signature", description = "Description")

    bro = GenericTestMechanism()

    # leave off bro.description = "Description"
    # leave off bro.specification = """some signature"""
    # leave off bro.type_ = "Bro"

    indicator.test_mechanisms = bro
    stix_package.add_indicator(indicator)

# will emit "can't call to_obj() on None type"

```

items.title: If STIX_Package/@id isn't set, provide a clearer error message
items.body:
See: https://github.com/crits/crits/issues/302

Currently, if the version attribute is not set on a `STIX_Package`, this error message gets generated: `No version attribute set on xml instance. Unable to determine version compatibility`

IMO, if the error message was something like `No version attribute set on STIX_Package. Unable to determine version compatibility.`, this would help provide some context when the error gets passed up the chain to the calling application (as it is in this case).

This might also apply to `STIX_Package/Indicators/Indicator/@version`.

-Mark

items.title: to_xml of STIX entity ignores additional entries in ns_dict
items.body:
When auto_namspace is set to True in the to_xml-method, then ns_dict is completely ignored. The ns_dict, however, seems to be the only way to add namespace information other than the namspace of the entity identifer. For example, I create a STIX object with entities for which I set the idref-Attribute to "some_other_ns:identifier". In earlier STIX versions, I would add an entry mapping the URL associated with the "some_other_ns" to the ns_dict, and it would be included in the namespaces. Now, the namespace are pruned nicely, but this additional namespace is left out.

Would it be possible to add an option with which the inclusion of the namespaces passed in ns_dict is forced? Or is there some other way of adding namespace info that I am overlooking?

items.title: Error when exporting integer attributes
items.body:
``` python
>>> from stix.incident.affected_asset import AssetType
>>> at = AssetType()
>>> at.count_affected = 1
>>> print at.to_xml()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "stix/base.py", line 80, in to_xml
    namespacedef_=namespace_def)
  File "stix/bindings/incident.py", line 2119, in export
    self.exportAttributes(lwrite, level, already_processed, namespace_, name_='AssetTypeType')
  File "stix/bindings/incident.py", line 2131, in exportAttributes
    lwrite(' count_affected=%s' % (self.gds_format_string(quote_attrib(self.count_affected).encode(ExternalEncoding), input_name='count_affected'), ))
  File "stix/bindings/__init__.py", line 271, in quote_attrib
    return saxutils.quoteattr(text)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/xml/sax/saxutils.py", line 66, in quoteattr
    data = escape(data, entities)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/xml/sax/saxutils.py", line 32, in escape
    data = data.replace("&", "&")
AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute 'replace'
>>> 
```

We can probably replace [this line](https://github.com/STIXProject/python-stix/blob/d573cd28427515aaa6b2b769113170061bf32c74/stix/bindings/__init__.py#L271)

```
return saxutils.quoteattr(text)
```

with 

```
return saxutils.quoteattr(str(text))
```

We should probably look at `quote_xml` as well.

items.title: invalid XML generated with CIQIdentity3_0Instance
items.body:
Hi,

I'm trying to put Country info into an IdentityField, using the followin Python code:

``` python
from stix.core import STIXPackage
from stix.ttp import TTP
from stix.ttp.victim_targeting import VictimTargeting
from stix.extensions.identity.ciq_identity_3_0 import (CIQIdentity3_0Instance,
                                                       Address, Country)

ttp = TTP()
victim = VictimTargeting()
identity = CIQIdentity3_0Instance()
identity.name = 'Old Man Podemkin'
identity.specification.add_address(Address(country=Country("Elbonia")))
victim.identity = identity
ttp.victim_targeting = victim

pkg = STIXPackage()
pkg.add_ttp(ttp)
print pkg.to_xml()
```

Is this how it's supposed to be done, or am I overcomplicating things?
The generated XML doesn't validate according to stix-validator:

```
[!] /tmp/wop2.xml:23:0:ERROR:SCHEMASV:SCHEMAV_ELEMENT_CONTENT: Element '{http://stix.mitre.org/extensions/Identity#CIQIdentity3.0-1}Name': This element is not expected. Expected is one of ( {http://stix.mitre.org/common-1}Name, {http://stix.mitre.org/common-1}Related_Identities, {http://stix.mitre.org/extensions/Identity#CIQIdentity3.0-1}Specification ).
```

The generated xml:

``` xml
                <ttp:Identity id="example:Identity-9f3ea10c-dfef-4480-a837-3457cc516d49" xsi:type='stix-ciqidentity:CIQIdentity3.0InstanceType'>
                    <stix-ciqidentity:Name>Old Man Podemkin</stix-ciqidentity:Name>
```

(Note that I'm not using the plain stix.common.Identity as I don't know how to put country information in it..)

Regards,
Jasper

items.title: Implement to_dict on MAECInstance
items.body: The `MAECInstance` malware extension class does not have a `to_dict()` method. As such, it's `super(...).to_dict()` method is invoked in its place.

script.py

``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python
# Copyright (c) 2014, The MITRE Corporation. All rights reserved.
# See LICENSE.txt for complete terms.

'''
File: ex_01.py

Description: Round-trip example. This script takes a STIX instance document from XML to
a binding object, then to a api object and then to a dictionary. That dictionary is then
converted back into an api object, which is then used to generate an XML document.
'''

import io
from pprint import pprint

from stix.core import STIXPackage

def main():
   fn = 'input.xml'
   stix_package = STIXPackage.from_xml(fn)
   stix_dict = stix_package.to_dict() # parse to dictionary
   pprint(stix_dict)

   stix_package_two = STIXPackage.from_dict(stix_dict) # create python-stix object from dictionary
   xml = stix_package_two.to_xml() # generate xml from python-stix object
   print(xml)

if __name__ == '__main__':
   main()
```

items.title: Namespace issue with YaraTestMechanismType
items.body:
Described here: https://github.com/STIXProject/stixproject.github.io/pull/124

Basically, there are two different namespaces being generated for the YaraTestMechanismType: one at the top of the document and one inline

``` xml
xmlns:yaraTM="http://stix.mitre.org/extensions/TestMechanism#YARA-1"
xmlns:yaraTM='http://stix.mitre.org/extensions/TestMechanism#Yara-1'
```

The top one is correct.

items.title: ID Namespace Example causes warning
items.body:
When running the example for ID Namespaces [1], I get the following warning: `site-packages\stix\utils\nsparser.py:161: UserWarning: Unable to map namespace 'http://MY-NAMESPACE.com' to schemaLocation  "schemaLocation" % ns)`

Valid XML is produced, so I'm really just filing this issue about the warning. My guess is that ID namespaces don't really need to be present in the schemaLocation element.

This is probably a pretty low priority.
-Mark

[1] http://stix.readthedocs.org/en/latest/examples/index.html#id-namespaces

items.title: Should Indicator.add_related_ttp take two arguments?
items.body:
Currently, if I want to add an indicated TTP to an Indicator and have a confidence, I have to do something like:

``` python
indicator = Indicator()
indicator.add_indicated_ttp(TTP(idref=ttp.id_))
indicator.indicated_ttps[0].confidence = "High"
```

I'm not sure how I'd assert the confidence on multiple indicated TTPs. I'd probably walk the indicated_ttps array, but that would require knowledge of how the API stores the TTPs under the hood (e.g., are new ones added to the front or the back of the array?).

I'd propose changing add_indicated_ttp to take a second argument of confidence. Then I could do something like:

``` python
indicator = Indicator()
indicator.add_indicated_ttp(TTP(idref='some_id'), confidence="High")
```

It also might be useful to have a `get_indicated_ttp(...)` method that retrieves a TTP based on the ID of the TTP. That way, if I later decide I want to change the confidence of an indicated TTP, I could do something like:

``` python
indicated_ttp = indicator.get_indicated_ttp('some_id')
indicated_ttp.confidence = "Low"
```

items.title: Going round-trip results in schema violations (TOUMarking:Terms_Of_Use)
items.body:
Ingesting  XML containing `TOUMarking:Terms_Of_Use` via `from_xml()`

``` xml
<stix:Handling>
    <marking:Marking>
             <marking:Controlled_Structure>//node()</marking:Controlled_Structure>
             <marking:Marking_Structure xsi:type="TOUMarking:TermsOfUseMarkingStructureType">
               <TOUMarking:Terms_Of_Use>TERMS OF USE</TOUMarking:Terms_Of_Use>
             </marking:Marking_Structure>
      </marking:Marking>
</stix:Handling>
```

converting to python object using `to_dict()` then back to XML via `to_xml()` results in the following namespaces

``` xml
<stix:STIX_Package 
    xmlns:marking="http://data-marking.mitre.org/Marking-1"
    xmlns:TOUMarking="http://data-marking.mitre.org/extensions/MarkingStructure#Terms_Of_Use-1"
    xmlns:stixCommon="http://stix.mitre.org/common-1"
    xmlns:stixVocabs="http://stix.mitre.org/default_vocabularies-1"
    xmlns:stix="http://stix.mitre.org/stix-1"
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xsi:schemaLocation="
    http://data-marking.mitre.org/Marking-1 http://stix.mitre.org/XMLSchema/data_marking/1.1.1/data_marking.xsd
    http://data-marking.mitre.org/extensions/MarkingStructure#Terms_Of_Use-1 http://stix.mitre.org/XMLSchema/extensions/marking/terms_of_use/1.0/terms_of_use_marking.xsd
    http://stix.mitre.org/common-1 http://stix.mitre.org/XMLSchema/common/1.1.1/stix_common.xsd
    http://stix.mitre.org/default_vocabularies-1 http://stix.mitre.org/XMLSchema/default_vocabularies/1.1.1/stix_default_vocabularies.xsd
    http://stix.mitre.org/stix-1 http://stix.mitre.org/XMLSchema/core/1.1.1/stix_core.xsd" version="1.1.1">

</stix:STIX_Package>

```

items.title: API does not support short_description in the header
items.body: `Short_Description` is handled on all major construct classes with the exception of STIXHeader

items.title: Preserve the custom namespace prefixes of the passed document (via a non_stix_dict)
items.body:
One can override STIX namespace aliases on export with the `ns_dict` parameter on `to_xml()`:

``` python

# tested on v1.1.1.1

print package.to_xml(ns_dict={'http://stix.mitre.org/stix-1': 'TEST'})
```

Non-default namespace aliases are not preserved on a round-trip, so if "http://stix.mitre.org/stix-1" was mapped to a "foo" alias on an input document, that document would be exported with a "stix" namespace alias unless the `ns_dict` parameter remaps that namespace to a non-"stix" alias.  This behavior of the `ns_dict` parameter is only applicable to STIX constructs.

Using the `ns_dict` parameter of the `.to_xml()` method requires the developer to know what prefixes to include. This is easier if you're only creating your own documents but if you're ingesting documents from various creators the developer won't know all of the prefixes beforehand.

Could the stix/utils/parser/EntityParser create a dictionary of all the non-"stix" prefixes, urls, schemalocations? This `non_stix_dict` could then be passed(configurable) to the `.to_xml()` method and the developer wouldn't have to know all possible incoming prefixes. 

Alternatively the developer would have parse the file outside of the API to get this information then create a dictionary and pass it as the ns_dict parameter to the .to_xml() method. Having it in the API would reduce an extra parse and work and the incoming STIX document.

items.title: Create "TypedList" abstraction
items.body: The `EntityList` class assumes that there is an underlying STIX type, but there are plenty of cases where there is a field with multiplicity >1, and we want to check the type of each item added to the list. The `EntityList` class could also derive from this new type.

items.title: Character encoding in XML
items.body:
Hi there,

we noticed that strings which are being passed to stix/cybox objects (e.g. in description fields) later are outputted 'as is' in the resulting XML document. This will result in invalid XML when unsafe characters are provided (e.g. an ampersand). Below is the 'indicator-simplehash.py' from your examples directory with an ampersand in the STIX header description field.

``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python
# Copyright (c) 2014, The MITRE Corporation. All rights reserved.
# See LICENSE.txt for complete terms.
'''
Description: Build a STIX Observables document
'''

from stix.core import STIXPackage, STIXHeader
from cybox.common import Hash
from cybox.objects.file_object import File

def main():
    shv = Hash()
    shv.simple_hash_value = "4EC0027BEF4D7E1786A04D021FA8A67F"
    f = File()
    h = Hash(shv, Hash.TYPE_MD5)
    f.add_hash(h)
    stix_package = STIXPackage()
    stix_header = STIXHeader()
    stix_header.description = "Examples & more"
    stix_package.stix_header = stix_header
    stix_package.add_observable(f)
    print(stix_package.to_xml())

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

The resulting document then contains

``` xml
...
<stix:STIX_Header>
  <stix:Description>Examples & more</stix:Description>
</stix:STIX_Header>
...
```

which fails validation. In my opinion the stix library should make sure that characters are encoded properly when XML output is generated.

Looking forward to your feedback!

Best regards,
Stefan

This issue was created as a result of me typing `cd .. <enter>` into what I thought was a command prompt. Well, now my mistake is cast in stone for all eternity because you can't delete GitHub issues.

From a community member:

```
        Input:
                <ttp:Intended_Effect />
        Output:
                <ttp:Intended_Effect>
                         <stixCommon:Value xsi:type="stixVocabs:HighMediumLowVocab-1.0"/>
                </ttp:Intended_Effect>

items.title: ns_dict param on to_xml() can render invalid XML
items.body:
The `ns_dict` param on `to_xml()` allows users to define new namespace aliases for non-STIX namespaces. However, if a STIX or CybOX namespace alias is overridden, `to_xml()` can render schema-invalid XML.

Example:

``` python
package = STIXPackage.from_xml('STIX_IP_Watchlist.xml')
print package.to_xml(ns_dict={'http://cybox.mitre.org/cybox-2': 'foo'})
```

The output includes `xmlns:foo="http://cybox.mitre.org/cybox-2"` but CybOX XML elements still use a `cybox` namespace alias, such as `<cybox:Object id="example:Object-1980ce43-8e03-490b-863a-ea404d12242e">`

**Solution:**
The `ns_dict` param should not allow users to modify default aliases for STIX/CybOX namespaces.

items.title: CIQ Identity type should support nationalities
items.body: It's used by the APT1 example and probably is relatively common in threat actor descriptions.

items.title: CIQ Identity type seems incomplete for names
items.body:
Our example content uses `PartyName/PersonName` and `PartyName/OrganisationName` for names, but the API only seems to support the more generic `PartyName/NameElement`.

The API should support the more specific types to correspond with our suggested practices.

items.title: Reconsider which constructs get ids by default
items.body: In 1.1.1.1 `MalwareInstanceType` (and potentially others) get an auto-assigned `@id` by default. This can be removed by setting it to `None` but debatably should be excluded by default as it's a more advanced usage.

items.title: Suppress the version attribute on major components by default
items.body:
The STIX suggested practice for `@version` is to omit it unless you're changing it from the default. The APIs should follow this and omit it unless the producer sets it something else.

Note: this can currently be accomplished by manually setting the attribute to `None`, I mean that it should be omitted by default unless it's manually set.

items.title: Add support for IndicatorType/@negate
items.body: Currently seems to be hard-coded to false. Probably should be omitted by default w/ the option to manually set it.
